reasoning: The critique targets a key step in Sec. 3.2: that linear-unbounded views are fussy because (i) near-best requires using most resources and (ii) most uses are far worse than the best due to a fat-tailed value-efficiency distribution and an effectively unique optimal arrangement. Undermining (ii) would significantly weaken (though not wholly collapse) the essay’s broader “no easy eutopia” conclusion, since the essay also argues for fussiness via other routes (fragility/product-of-factors, bounded views, bads sensitivity, etc.). Hence moderate centrality. As a countermodel, it has real force: if value-per-resource has a broad near-optimal plateau and the heavy tail is mainly on the downside (rare traps) rather than upside (rare bonanzas), then the ‘very specific use’/narrow-target claim is not established by the analogies offered, and the conclusion flips toward “avoid anti-patterns” rather than “hit a needle.” However, the critique doesn’t show that the plateau model is more plausible than the author’s fat-tail-upside story; it mainly shows underdetermination and a missing argument, so it weakens rather than refutes. Most statements are plausible and appropriately conditional, though it arguably overstates the original’s commitment to a literally single arrangement (the position suggests ‘some very specific kind(s) of thing’ rather than uniqueness). Clear, focused on one issue, with minimal extraneous material.
title: Broad-plateaued value efficiency undermines the single optimal arrangement assumption
